@Advanced users

This video runs at 29.971 fps but every fifth frame is a duplicate. So there are still only 24 unique frames per second. This will annoy some viewers since every fifth frame is shown twice as long as the other frames. A solution is to run it in AviSynth with Decimate(5), which ignores the duplicate frames and runs the video 24 fps.

Fix for the Audio Video sync problem:
-------------------------------------------

The Problem:
---------------

The Audio is delayed by 2900 ms == 2.9 seconds - plus - it?s too long for the normal 29.970 fps (frames per second), it needs to be 29.989 fps.

This way the Audio starts at the correct time and the video rate lines up with the Audio.


The Solution:
---------------

TO FIX I used: "AviDemux" from: http://avidemux.sourceforge.net/

Download the ZIP file under ?Windows? - 2.5.2 ZIP from either link: Berlios.de or SourceForge.

Note: This program (using the zip file) is StandAlone so no install is required.

Just extract the files to somewhere you?re going to use it from (eg: Downloads or DownloadsRun or DownloadsRunAviDemux ).


Click the applcation called: avidemux2_gtk


Once AviDemux is running, it?s easy to change an MP4?s sync and rate - which is what the problem is here.


AviDemux program
----------------------

- Drag and drop the MP4 file (Avatar.mp4) into the AviDemux -or- Open it using File | Open | etc..


- Under Video - leave it on ?Copy?


- Under Audio - leave it on ?Copy?

- Under Audio - check the ?Shift? box

- Under Audio - next to 'Shift', type the negative number: -2900


- Under Format: select ?MP4?


- On the Top Menu: Click ?Video? go down to ?Frame Rate? type the exact number: 29.989 then click: OK


- Select the range using the bottom slider to ?mark? the ?start? and ?end? of the Copy you?re making.

- With the slider at the beginning of the movie: click button: A

- Next with the slider at the end of the movie: click button: B


- Now you are ready: click the ?Save? button and select a name (eg: Avatar-fix.mp4)


Note: No encoding is done so it?s very Fast and there is No Loss of Quality !!!


Note2: If you want to encode/burn to a dvd you?ll most likely have to rencode it from the fixed 29.989 delayed 2.9 secs copy you just made to a remuxed copy. This is since some dvd software assumes (and will set) the frame rate back to the standard 29.970 and ignore the Audio delay you put in. Your dvd will be out of sync the same as the download was.

You can use AviDux to do this, however that is beyond the scope of what I?m trying to help with here.


Note3: Enjoy !


Thx Uploader !!!!! whoever you are...

Very much appreciated after about 15 downloads and a waste of the internet?s bandwidth - sorry Cisco ... (they route most of the traffic on the internet NA, huge water cooled rooms, etc..).

Have Fun.

Finally sorted out this FPS bullshit. Now it plays awesomely with MPC. Here is what you do:

* Download and install avisynth.

* Download the Decomb plugin from here: http://avisynth.org/warpenterprises/files/decomb522_25_dll_20050904.zip - extract contents to the plugins folder of avisynth (start menu > avisynth 2.5 > plugin directory)

* Create a new text file in the folder where you downloaded the movie, and name the file FixedAvatar.avs (make sure file extension is avs and not txt). In the file, enter the following:

LoadPlugin("C:\Program Files\AviSynth 2.5\plugins\Decomb.dll")
DirectShowSource("Avatar.mp4")
Decimate(5)

* In MPC, go to View>Options>Audio Switcher, and enable audio shift and set it to -1900 (not -2900 like have said). It's kinda tricky to enter a negative value, since the edit box won't accept the "-" key. You can type -1900 in notepad, copy it, and just paste it there.

* Open the avs file in MPC. Just open MPC and drop the avs on it.

* Enjoy the movie.

* All hail the hikki man

You can test that the extra every 5th frame is removed by pausing the video and pressing the right arrow to play frame by frame. If you do this with the original file, you'll see that every 5th frame is a copy of the 4th frame, causing the video to feel funny for the trained eye.
- Thanks to JPeterson for his enlightening remark.
